instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM Beeps--Anything to check before replacing RAM chips?
threads.message:
Pretty straightforward issue I think, but wanted to confirm:

1. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> beeps immediately when powered on; typical 3-beep tone indicating RAM issue.
2. No damage, no liquid, apparently no drops.
3. <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> present, not shorted.
4. Is there anything I should check prior to pricing out replacing the RAM chips? I assume not, but wanted to confirm.

Thanks for any assistance in advance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> RAM Beeps--Anything to check before replacing RAM chips?
threads.message: Could be cracked traces too, bad CPU or other issue. I do not fix boards with these issues, but if you want to try I would start with the RAM chips.
